issues.description: Inconsistent getter naming for StockIngredient across template and solution repositories. The template repository's StockIngredient exposes the ingredient name via getIngredientName(), and the template Stock.findStockIngredient() calls getIngredientName(). In the solution repository the getter is named getName(), and the solution's Stock.findStockIngredient() calls getName(). The problem statement asks students to "add getters for all the private fields" but does not mandate specific getter names. This difference in method names between template and solution is an unintentional structural inconsistency that can confuse students who compare their work with the provided solution or whose tests/reference expect a consistent getter name.
issues.suggested_fix:
Unify the getter name for the ingredient's name across template and solution. Two options:
- Rename template's getIngredientName() to getName() and update all references (e.g., Stock.findStockIngredient) to call getName(), making it consistent with Meal.getName(). Or
- Change the solution to use getIngredientName() (and update its Stock.findStockIngredient accordingly) if that naming is preferred. Also update the problem statement to explicitly state the expected getter names (or note that any conventional getter name is acceptable) to avoid ambiguity.

issues.description: The StockIngredient 'name' field is exposed with different getter names across artifacts: the template uses getIngredientName() while the solution uses getName(). The problem statement's class diagram refers to the StockIngredient concept but does not prescribe a getter name. This divergence (getIngredientName vs getName) creates an avoidable mapping burden for students comparing template, problem description, and reference solution — students may be unsure which getter name to implement/use and could waste time reconciling the two versions.
issues.suggested_fix: Standardize the getter name for the StockIngredient 'name' field across template and solution. Prefer getName() (aligns with common getter conventions and the solution). Update the template: rename getIngredientName() to getName() and adjust all usages in Stock and elsewhere to call getName(). Alternatively, if you prefer the more descriptive form, change the solution to use getIngredientName() everywhere — but keep the name consistent across all artifacts.
